description: From Latin parapherna, and ultimately from Ancient Greek παρά (pará) + φερνή (phernḗ) (“things additional to a dowry”). In the propertied classes, a dowry was placed under the control of the husband, while the 'paraphernalia' which she brought with her remained the wife’s property.

entries.meaning: (law, historical, Ancient Rome) A woman's property which was not made a part of her marriage dower but remained her own.
